unit.title: Writing for Purpose: Letters, Diaries, and Digital Etiquette
unit.overview: Learners practise purpose-driven writing: informal and formal letters, diary entries, and safe, respectful digital communication. The unit emphasises register, structure, cohesion, and moral responsibility online. All lessons are bite-sized, with AI scaffolds, XP hooks, and British English conventions.
competencies: Distinguish purpose, audience, and register across writing tasks.
Apply correct structure and conventions for informal and formal letters (British style).
Write a coherent diary entry using time order and reflective tone.
Demonstrate safe, respectful digital communication in short-form messages.
Edit writing for cohesion, punctuation, and spelling.
values_morals: Truthfulness and respect in all forms of communication.
Digital responsibility: speak with gentleness and integrity (Proverbs 15:1).

lessons.title: Purpose & Audience: Choosing the Right Register
objectives: Identify purpose and audience for different tasks.
Choose formal vs informal register appropriately.

vocabulary.definition: The reason for communication (inform, persuade, request, etc.).

lessons.moral_link: Respect your reader—your tone reflects your character.

content_blocks.body: Match tone to audience: headteacher (formal), friend (informal), parent (respectful).

content_blocks.caption: Register scale from informal to formal.

items.label: Formal

items.scenario: Texting your best friend about homework

items.label: Formal

quick_check.q: Which closing suits a formal letter?

lessons.title: Informal Letters (British Style)
objectives: Use correct informal letter layout (address/date optional in digital context, greeting, body, closing).
Maintain friendly tone, clear paragraphs, and basic punctuation.

vocabulary.definition: Greeting at the start of a letter (e.g., Dear Ama,).
An added note after the main message (P.S.).

content_blocks.body: Model: Dear Kofi, … (friendly tone, short paragraphs, sign‑off: Yours truly,/Your friend,).
Keep one idea per paragraph; avoid slang that may confuse.

lessons.title: Formal Letters (British Style)
objectives: Apply correct British formal letter layout: sender’s address, date, receiver’s address, salutation, subject line (optional), body, closing, signature.
Use ‘Yours faithfully,’ when salutation is ‘Dear Sir/Madam,’ and ‘Yours sincerely,’ when the recipient is named.

vocabulary.definition: A short heading stating the purpose of the letter.

lessons.moral_link: Respect authority and be concise and truthful in requests.

content_blocks.body: Use clear paragraphs: introduction (purpose), details (evidence), courteous request, closing.

reorder_blocks.prompt: Arrange the parts of a formal letter in correct order.

ai_task.prompt: Write a formal letter to your headteacher requesting permission to start a reading club. Keep it respectful, concise, and persuasive.

lessons.title: Diary Writing: Reflect & Grow
objectives: Write a reflective diary entry using time order and feelings vocabulary.
Use first person and consistent tense; close with a brief insight or prayer if preferred.

vocabulary.definition: A deep understanding of a person or situation.

lessons.moral_link: Self-examination helps build character and gratitude.

content_blocks.body: Typical features: date/time, first‑person voice, feelings/thoughts, events in sequence, closing insight.

content_blocks.caption: Key elements of a diary entry.

lessons.title: Digital Etiquette: Safe & Respectful Messaging
objectives: Write short digital messages (email/SMS/WhatsApp) using polite register and clarity.
Apply safety: no personal data sharing, no bullying; think before posting.

vocabulary.definition: Rules for proper behaviour on the internet.
Concise and exact use of words.

lessons.moral_link: Let your speech be gracious, seasoned with salt (Colossians 4:6).

content_blocks.body: Be brief, clear, and kind. Avoid forwarding rumours. Ask permission before sharing images.

error_hunt.text: pls send me ur notes NOW!!! also add kofi’s number here
tasks: Fix tone, spelling, capitalisation, and remove unsafe request.
error_hunt.solution_hint: Be polite, use sentence case, and never request someone’s personal number publicly.
